prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on observations of sub-mm galaxies and theoretical models (Davies et al. 2012) we estimate that 10$^8$ M$_{\odot}$ of dust at 30K will produce 0.4mJy of emission in the continuum at 850 $\mu$m. At a minimum we will require a 5 $\sigma$ detection in Band 7 of the ALMA array. As shown in Figure 2, the sources are well within the field of view also of the most compact configuration and the achievable resolution would suffice to at least carry out some mapping of the dust distribution, although this depends on the dust content and surface brightness. We have divided our sample into four groups (two groups of four galaxies and one group contains only 1). To observe all galaxies in the first two group of four targets (our highest priority) would require 2 h. Our scientific aims for this pilot program could be realized even if one of the groups is not observed

We have divided our sample into four groups (two groups of four galaxies and one group contains only 1). To observe all galaxies in the first two group of four targets (our highest priority) would require 2 h. Our scientific aims for this pilot program could be realized even if one of the groups is not observed

At a minimum we will require a 5 $\sigma$ detection in Band 7 of the ALMA array. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain images of 11 low redshift K+A galaxies selected from the Las Campanas Redshift Survey and possessing vast amounts of ancillary data, such as spectra, optical and infrared imaging, 20cm data, X-rays and ACS imaging from HST. We will measure the $870$ $\mu$m continuum flux as a proxy for CO emission and hence measure the quantity of molecular gas encountered in these objects. This will allow us to determine whether K+A galaxies are being observed during a temporary hiatus in star formation or have been definitively quenched into red sequence galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Bristol, University of
